awd_titl_txt: Workshop: RoL:FELS: Invasion Biology Rules of Life; March 25-28, 2019, West Greenwich, Rhode Island
awd_abstract_narration:
A principal product of globalization is the introduction and spread of non-native species, with many of these species reducing biodiversity or imposing substantial harm to our economy, agriculture, and human health. This workshop will bring together scientists from data science and diverse areas of biology to build an integrated understanding of the "rules" by which organismal biology combines with local ecological conditions to allow invasive species to expand their range and impact ecosystem function. Participants have expertise across a wide variety of organisms and ecosystems, including plants, animals, and microbes living in terrestrial, freshwater, and marine environments. The goal of the workshop is to develop novel interdisciplinary approaches and perspectives that strengthen our understanding of invasive species impacts and how these impacts vary across locations. Such insights will fill critical knowledge gaps related to preventing and managing invasive species at the local, state, and national levels. The results will be shared through scientific publications, news media, and direct interactions with the National Invasive Species Council. 

This workshop on the invasion biology rules of life will integrate largely distinct research approaches to enhance scientific understanding of invasion spread and impacts. Key objectives are to improve (1) prediction of both establishment of a non-native species and invasion impacts on native species and ecological processes, at more highly resolved spatial and temporal scales and (2) methods of integrating invasion observations from citizens and scientists into more highly detailed databases that, in turn, can depict not only occurrences of non-native species but also impacts. Both objectives will lead to more effective prediction and management of invasion impacts and better policies to support these goals. Participants will link mechanistic models of invasion spread, based on physiological and other traits, to species distribution models based on various statistical treatments of geographically structured environmental data. They will then assess whether the linked models produce better predictions of invasion impacts at scales relevant to management and direct researchers toward better understanding of why impacts of particular invaders vary greatly across space and time. In addition, the workshop will evaluate how best to assemble and use invasive species data gathered from a wide range of sources into integrated databases that aid research on invasion processes and impacts and assist managers and policymakers in efficiently responding to potential and actual invasions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biological invasions are a key component of global change and have caused and will continue to cause substantial harm to biodiversity, human health, and economies. Rates of establishment of non-native species have risen exponentially over the last several decades across most taxa and all ecosystem types. Invasion science has grown in relevance, but better integration is still needed across scientific sub-fields and across spatial and temporal scales to more effectively prevent, manage, and mitigate invasions. A primary barrier to developing invasive species’ impact theories is that they integrate biological mechanisms that span from individuals up to whole ecosystems complicating how individual organisms interact with each other and their environment.

 

We organized a week-long workshop to explore approaches to explain and predict invasive species’ impacts. The workshop, funded by the National Science Foundation Rules of Life initiative, took place in May 2019 at the Alton Jones Campus of the University of Rhode Island. Participants were intentionally chosen from a range of scientific backgrounds to ensure neglected aspects of biological invasions were included. We took a broad, multidisciplinary approach by bringing together population and community ecologists with physiologists and data scientists to explore how organisms respond and adapt to dynamic and stressful environments. We identified approaches to the analysis of invasive species’ evolutionary adaptation, range expansion, and ecological impacts through the explicit recognition of a fundamental link between an organism’s physiology and its environment and how this relationship varies through space and time. We found that the range expansion and ecological impacts of invasive species can be viewed as a problem of ecological and physiological integration across biological scales from individuals up to ecosystems and landscapes.

We took the three related approaches to exploring biological, spatial, and temporal scales that were our focus for the workshop: mechanistic physiological models of invasive species distributions, the physiological basis of invasive species ecological impacts, and insights resulting from data integration that allows research on biological integration. Thus far, we have three manuscripts (one published, one in review, one in preparation) that have resulted from the workshop, one talk at the Ecological Society of America Annual Meeting and one planned talk at the Annual Meeting for the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology 2022.

Publications:

 

1.     Meyerson, LA, D Simberloff, L Boardman, J Lockwood. 2019. Towards “rules” for studying biological invasions. Bulletin of the Ecological Society of America. Bull Ecol Soc Am https://doi.org/10.1002/bes2.1607

 

  • This paper summarizes the outcomes of the workshop, namely:

o   the importance of the intersection between eco-physiology and invasion biology, especially how inter-disciplinary approaches can inform fundamental questions about invasive species spread and impact

o   the need to develop SDM/ENM approaches in invasion science that can motivate and be integrated with physiological research to provide a mechanistic understanding of likely spread and limits of invasive species

o   identification of understudied mechanisms of invasions, such as physiological response impacts over multiple spatial and temporal scales under environmental change

 

2.     Boardman, L, M Angilletta, J Krause, J Lau, Julie Lockwood, Michael Loik, Dan Simberloff, Christopher Thawley, and Laura A. Meyerson. (In Review). The future of invasion science needs physiology. BioScience.

o   This manuscript details how physiological processes affect every invasion stage and how physiological data can be better used for studying the spatial dynamics and ecological effects of invasive species. It then outlines six steps for quantifying the physiological functions related to demography of non-native species and calls for closer collaboration between ecophysiologists and invasion scientists.

 

3.     Gotelli, N, C Merow, J Krauss, M Angiletta, J Lockwood, D Simberloff, L Boardman, LA Meyerson. In preparation. Forecasting models for invasive species.

o   This manuscript explores and uses a case study to test how species distribution models (SDM, also known as environmental niche models, ENM) in invasion ecology can motivate and be integrated with physiological research to provide a mechanistic understanding of the projected spread and limits of invasive species. We expect this manuscript to be submitted in early 2022.

4.     Crystal-Ornelas, R.C., M.C. Allen, and J.L. Lockwood.  In prep. Data taming in invasion science:  making management models useable and used.  Biological Invasions. We expect this manuscript to be submitted early 2022.

 

 

Presentations:

1.     Lockwood, J.L., and M.C. Allen. Data taming in invasion science:  bridging the gap between models and their implementation.  202. Annual Meeting of the Ecological Society of American Meeting, Virtual.  

2.     Boardman, L, M Angilletta, J Krause, J Lau, Julie Lockwood, Michael Loik, Dan Simberloff, Christopher Thawley, and Laura A. Meyerson. January 2022. Physiologists! Invasion Science Needs Your Data! Annual Meeting for the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology, 2022.
